Well I didn't get much detail but apparently the teachers union in somewhere in Oregon was negotiating for higher salaries and the government said no. So they decided to have a no-homework policy in protest so they wouldn't have to do as much work. They've said if they get paid more than they will do more work, grade the homework. I'm sure the kids in the school are loving it.

must be elemetry. Highschool and universties have a tendency to outsource their grading to hired students, so higher salaries for teachers is irrevelant when it comes to grading hw.

 High School and Unversities don't hire student's to grade homework, their not going to pay someone else to do the teachers job. They do however assign Teacher's Aide's and students get credit for it. Not all homework however, can be graded by the Teacher's Aide. Certain assignment's may still be gradeable only by the teacher.

I'm sorry if this is bad... but i would love to have no hw... i live in wash, i hope it spreads upward

 The government here had no choice but to say no. Any increase in taxes and/or public service must be approved by a majority popular vote. The public says no, their increases were sucked up by federal reporting requirements requiring two testing procedures in the 'No child left behind' fraud. Now the teachers union is attempting to divert highway patrol funding for salary increases. 
 
 Isn't the teacher action similar to a physician partially fixing a broken arm until the patient comes up with more money? Professional ethics sinking to new lows through unionization and tenure.

 Well I've found that most (not all) homework is just busywork. I've heard that parents will complain if their kids don't get enough homework. I have several teachers that just automatically have homework every class. Some teachers that do this actually have a need to do this, but for some it's just to give homework, not to help us learn or understand anything or practice. It's just mindless busywork.

 I agree, I've never heard of people hiring students to do grading. But a lot of high school teachers get teachers aids who grade pretty much everything, even our final exams.
georged

I agree, I've never heard of people hiring students to do grading. But a lot of high school teachers get teachers aids who grade pretty much everything, even our final exams.

 
 Grade consideration isn't a form of payment to reduce teacher work time? 
 
 At the college level in past generations a lot of the grading in science and liberal arts was done by grad students. High school level grading of exam results by student aides was generally unheard of. 
 
 Would you attribute the change to a generally accepted feeling that quality of education has slipped to where current undergrad college curriculum is at a level formerly occupied by high school requirements? I'm not referring to hard sciences pursued by a somewhat limited number of students, but general education.

High School and Unversities don't hire student's to grade homework, their not going to pay someone else to do the teachers job.

 
 On the contrary, many universities use students to grade hw, as stipulated in a work study scholarship. not to mention many students in highschool are paid to score tests, as well as some homeworks. Usually the students are in a higher grade then the course they are grading. 
 
 
They do however assign Teacher's Aide's and students get credit for it. Not all homework however, can be graded by the Teacher's Aide. Certain assignment's may still be gradeable only by the teacher.

 Do you mean as in give you work or just find out what your homework was? It really doesn't matter the details but it seems that many parents think that kids need homework to use up their time at home. And teachers do that as well by just giving homework for the sake of giving homework. If it is relevant and will help, fine. If it's just busiwork to take up time, I ask: What's the point?

 In my case my father knew that a little extra would do us good. He was not always around because of shift-work at the nearby steel plant, but when he was and we didn't have homework for him to check, he'd give us a page of math problems or give us a specific book to read. It wasn't a time-consuming affair, but enough to keep us busy after our chores were done.
 He was afraid that we'd get lazy and wind up working in a dirty mill or factory somewhere. I do the same thing with my kids. They hate it, but their good grades prove its worth. I have always believed that practice makes perfect.
georged

In my case my father knew that a little extra would do us good. It wasn't a time-consuming affair, but enough to keep us busy after our chores were done.
 He was afraid that we'd get lazy and wind up working in a dirty mill or factory somewhere. I do the same thing with my kids. They hate it, but their good grades prove its worth. I have always believed that practice makes perfect.

 
 Mine was a little more basic, but with the same intent; we followed rules while growing up, often grumbling about and questioning them. The major rule was that we followed the household rules. As I became older, I believe age 14 or so, I seriously questioned why my parents could make the rules and I had no input. My father pointed to the roof and stated as long as we were living under that roof and he and my mother were responsible for us, he had final say on the rules. Naturally that prompted me and a friend to run away from home, which lasted until about 10PM that night, when we decided the rules weren't all that bad considering that they were made by adults. I didn't realize it at the time, but that was probably when I accepted the fact that there were rules and what I did within those structures was my decision and would determine my course in life.
Alan Ryan

Homework was insisted upon at my high school (equivalent). My parents had to sign an "application card" 4 or 5 times a week to verify it had been done - without any help from anyone else ! I had to take the card to school every day and give it to the Prefect of Studies with my homework.
 
 I suppose that I first began to realise that I might end up better educated than my father, was when my Mathematics homework got above his head - and he was reckoned a pretty sharp man with figures.
zachvac

In my case my father knew that a little extra would do us good. He was not always around because of shift-work at the nearby steel plant, but when he was and we didn?t have homework for him to check, he?d give us a page of math problems or give us a specific book to read. It wasn?t a time-consuming affair, but enough to keep us busy after our chores were done.
 He was afraid that we?d get lazy and wind up working in a dirty mill or factory somewhere. I do the same thing with my kids. They hate it, but their good grades prove its worth. I have always believed that practice makes perfect.

 
 I don't need my parents to give me a specific book to read. I enjoy reading and do it when I can (usually right before bed for 45 minutes or so). I just think it's more important to understand the concept in terms of math then just be able to do it since you've done it repeatedly. That's why I don't like cramming for tests and why repetition shouldn't be how math is done (apart from multiplication tables, people should be able to multiply in their head). I never have the problem of keeping busy considering we have baseball practice and I don't get home until 6:30. After dinner it's 7:00-7:30 and I have homework and piano (40 minutes) to do. I'm lucky if I have time to do other stuff after that.
